Description: Ostracon, fragment (two pieces joined) from the body of a red-brown ribbed pottery vessel, fabric is black in section, interior covered with a brown resinous substance, exterior covered with a red/brown slip and remains of at least sixteen lines of Coptic text written in black ink, now very worn in places, containing an account of supplies.
Bibliographic references: Crum & Bell 1922 / Wadi Sarga: Coptic and Greek texts (p.120-121)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (87630) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/87630)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: O.Sarga 140 (text edition abbreviation according to Oates et al 2001)
